shredder 0.1.0

Working With brms

Source: vignettes/brms.Rmd
brms.Rmd
library(shredder)
library(brms)

Generate Data

group <- rep(c("treat", "placebo"), 
             each = 30)

symptom_post <- c(
  rnorm(30, mean = 1, sd = 2), 
  rnorm(30, mean = 0, sd = 1)
)

dat1 <- data.frame(group, symptom_post)

Run Model

fit <- brm(bf(symptom_post ~ group, sigma ~ group), 
           data = dat1, 
           family = gaussian())
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 4000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.30488   0.15692 -0.00771  0.60978       5473 0.99929
sigma_Intercept  -0.16113   0.13582 -0.40607  0.13028       2990 1.00009
grouptreat        0.77569   0.45365 -0.11526  1.66224       2334 1.00026
sigma_grouptreat  1.00180   0.19221  0.60599  1.37407       2760 0.99992

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Select first 100 Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_slice <- fit%>%stan_slice(1:100)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1100; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 400

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.30312   0.15587 -0.00396  0.59558        633 0.99513
sigma_Intercept  -0.15920   0.13425 -0.38586  0.12793        281 1.00668
grouptreat        0.78512   0.49101 -0.14536  1.72372        227 1.00200
sigma_grouptreat  1.01027   0.18782  0.63419  1.37332        347 0.99984

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_slice%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Sample 25% of Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_sample <- fit%>%
  stan_sample_frac(0.25)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1250; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 1000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.30142   0.15811 -0.01504  0.59517       1013 0.99799
sigma_Intercept  -0.15570   0.14170 -0.40916  0.13753       1048 1.00111
grouptreat        0.76549   0.45218 -0.14535  1.61899       1014 0.99792
sigma_grouptreat  0.99573   0.19814  0.59187  1.37332       1003 1.00041

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_sample%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional

fit_filter <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1002; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 8

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample Rhat
Intercept         0.23635   0.12541 -0.00134  0.35504          7  Inf
sigma_Intercept  -0.12321   0.11412 -0.25984  0.03995          7  Inf
grouptreat        2.12654   0.07375  2.01831  2.23310          7  Inf
sigma_grouptreat  1.13992   0.14574  0.88566  1.30407          7  Inf

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional Subset Chain

fit_filter_chain <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)%>%
  stan_retain(chains = 1)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 1 chains, each with iter = 1002; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 2

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample Rhat
Intercept         0.24928   0.04560  0.21865  0.27992          1  Inf
sigma_Intercept  -0.25419   0.01229 -0.26244 -0.24594          1  Inf
grouptreat        2.06312   0.07940  2.00978  2.11646          1  Inf
sigma_grouptreat  1.16762   0.06650  1.12295  1.21229          1  Inf

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter_chain%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)
